channel.title: Posts on Aerial
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Aerial

item.title: Bar Plots
item.description: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) Bar Plots are simply a visualization of data using bars. Below is a Bar Plot displaying each MLB team’s homerun totals in 1980. query<-"SELECT name,HR FROM Teams WHERE yearID=1980 ORDER BY HR" result<-sqldf(query) result$name<-factor(result$name,levels=result$name) ggplot()+ geom_bar(data=result,aes(x=name,y=HR),stat='identity',color="white",fill="blue")+ coord_flip()+ ylab("Homeruns")+ xlab("Teams")+ ggtitle("1980 Team Homerun Distribution")

item.title: Histograms
item.description: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) A histogram is a visual data representation using one column of data. In the code below, we made a histogram for body weight distribution of baseball players. query<-"SELECT weight FROM Master" result<-sqldf(query) ggplot()+ geom_histogram(data=result,aes(x=weight),color="green",fill="white",bins=50)+ ggtitle("Body Weight Distribution for Baseball Players") ## Warning: Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin).

item.title: Time Series
item.description: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) Time series are similiar to scatter plots because you can have points on the graph, but the major point that you are looking at with these are trends over time. Below is a Time Series displaying Babe Ruth’s home run totals over the years. # Extraction---------------------------- query<-"SELECT yearID,HR FROM Batting WHERE playerID='ruthba01'" result<-sqldf(query) # Visualization------------------------- ggplot()+ #geom_point(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+ geom_line(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+ ggtitle("Ruth's Homerun Totals Throughout the Years")+ xlab("Year")+ ylab("Homeruns")

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
